item.title: The UK launched a major test of the 4-day workweek
item.description: . In January, there were just 1,700 jobs advertising a four-day workweek in the US for every 1 million posted. Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. Bottom line: For all the notable trials and tests of a shorter workweek, finding a job that actually implements one is extremely rare. Trials of lighter work schedules haven‚Äôt always been successful for both employees and employers, though: A two-year trial of a six-hour workday in one of Sweden‚Äôs largest cities in 2017 left workers happier, healthier, and more productive, but the practice was deemed too expensive due to the new hires needed to fill gaps in time. More than 3,300 workers will participate in the trial, making it the largest test of the four-day workweek. A six-month program that began in the UK on Monday will test the effects of the four-day workweek on thousands of workers across 70 companies. ‚ÄîMK But, if you‚Äôre one of the 92% of US employees who are into the idea and don‚Äôt want to wait for trial results, you may want to consider moving to France, where a 35-hour workweek cap has been the law since 2000. The results of the trial will be announced sometime in 2023. Several industries will be involved, including banking, health care, marketing, and retail‚Äîand through interviews, surveys, and internal productivity measures, researchers will determine if we have all been clocking in on Fridays for our whole adult lives for absolutely no reason.

But first, he needs to continue producing good food and even better content until Gordon Ramsay comes knocking. It‚Äôs a laborious process that, for TikTok, was edited into a tidy 60-second video emphasizing the sounds of his kitchen: the boil of the broth, the sizzle of cooking oil, and Lee‚Äôs slurps as he eats his final product. item.title: NASA taps two companies to develop lunar spacesuits
item.description: . Become smarter in just 5 minutesGet the daily email that makes reading the news actually enjoyable. NASA will test the companies‚Äô suits in 2025, and then decide whether to fund one or both designs. One major reason for the holdup is that the necessary spacesuits won‚Äôt be ready on time. It‚Äôs been a leading aerospace supplier for decades and has supplied spacesuits to NASA before. Hoping to finally fix its spacesuit production snags, NASA announced this week that it awarded contracts to two teams led by private companies, Axiom Space and Collins Aerospace, to make its suits. NASA‚Äôs outsourcing is a tacit admission that its own work developing lunar suits in-house for 15 years has been too costly and time-consuming: As of August 2021, NASA‚Äôs spacesuit production schedule has suffered more than 20 months of delays. Construction of the rocket and the lunar lander have been set back by Covid-19 supply and labor challenges, as well as a legal scuffle between NASA and Jeff Bezos‚Äôs Blue Origin after NASA chose Elon Musk‚Äôs SpaceX to build the lander. In the end, the whole endeavor was such a slog that NASA finally decided to bring in Axiom Space and Collins Aerospace to help outfit its astronauts. Meanwhile, newcomer Axiom Space was founded in 2016 with the goal of building the first private space station. So, constructing a spacesuit is a Sisyphean task to start with, and NASA faced major hurdles trying to produce them in-house:1. Last year, NASA only received 77% of the funding it requested for part of the lunar program, resulting in a $69 million budget shortfall for suit development and a delay of at least three months. Looking ahead‚Ä¶even if NASA astronauts get the right gear to go to the moon in time, the lunar mission has to overcome several other major obstacles. *sigh*‚ÄîJW What‚Äôs the holdup, exactly?
